elements.content: The addition of chiral 2,2′-(2,6-pyridinediyl)bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazoline) (iPr-Pybox) to a self-assembled CoII–[WV(CN)8] magnetic system gives two enantiomorphic cyano-bridged chains, {[CoII((S,S)-iPr-Pybox)(MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2·​5.5MeOH·​0.5H2O} n (1-SS) and {[CoII((R,R)-iPr-Pybox) (MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2·​5.5MeOH·​0.5H2O} n (1-RR). Both compounds crystallize with a structure containing a unique crossed arrangement of one-dimensional chains that form a microporous supramolecular network with large channels (14.9 Å × 15.1 Å × 15.3 Å) filled with methanol. The investigated materials exhibited optical chirality, as confirmed by natural circular dichroism and UV–vis absorption spectra. 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) are paramagnets with cyano-mediated CoII–WV magnetic couplings that lead to a specific spin arrangement with half of the WV ions coupled ferromagnetically with their CoII neighbors and the other half coupled antiferromagnetically. Significant magnetic anisotropy with the easy axis along the [101] direction was confirmed by single-crystal magnetic studies and can be explained by the single-ion anisotropy of elongated octahedral CoII sites. Below 3 K, the frequency-dependent χM ″(T) signal indicated slow magnetic relaxation characteristic of single-chain magnets.
elements.clean_text: The addition of chiral 2,2'-(2,6-pyridinediyl)bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazoline) (iPr-Pybox) to a self-assembled CoII-[WV(CN)8] magnetic system gives two enantiomorphic cyano-bridged chains, {[CoII((S,S)-iPr-Pybox)(MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2⋅5.5MeOH⋅0.5H2O} n  (1-SS) and {[CoII((R,R)-iPr-Pybox) (MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2⋅5.5MeOH⋅0.5H2O} n  (1-RR). Both compounds crystallize with a structure containing a unique crossed arrangement of one-dimensional chains that form a microporous supramolecular network with large channels (14.9 Å × 15.1 Å × 15.3 Å) filled with methanol. The investigated materials exhibited optical chirality, as confirmed by natural circular dichroism and UV-vis absorption spectra. 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) are paramagnets with cyano-mediated CoII-WV magnetic couplings that lead to a specific spin arrangement with half of the WV ions coupled ferromagnetically with their CoII neighbors and the other half coupled antiferromagnetically. Significant magnetic anisotropy with the easy axis along the [101] direction was confirmed by single-crystal magnetic studies and can be explained by the single-ion anisotropy of elongated octahedral CoII sites. Below 3 K, the frequency-dependent χM "(T) signal indicated slow magnetic relaxation characteristic of single-chain magnets.

elements.content: The introduction of required additional properties to molecular magnets is being extensively investigated, as the interaction between the intrinsic magnetic nature and new functionalities leads to extraordinary cooperative effects such as magnetochiral dichroism, magnetic second-harmonic generation, and multiferroicity when chirality is combined with long-range magnetic ordering. Microporous magnets have also attracted enormous interest, as reversible guest exchange can significantly affect the magnetic character.
elements.clean_text: The introduction of required additional properties to molecular magnets is being extensively investigated, as the interaction between the intrinsic magnetic nature and new functionalities leads to extraordinary cooperative effects such as magnetochiral dichroism, magnetic second-harmonic generation, and multiferroicity when chirality is combined with long-range magnetic ordering. Microporous magnets have also attracted enormous interest, as reversible guest exchange can significantly affect the magnetic character.

elements.content: A considerable number of enantiopure chiral and microporous magnets have been characterized. Among them, extensive research has been devoted to cyano-bridged bimetallic assemblies, which exhibit a wide range of magnetic properties, including magnetic ordering, spin bistability, and magnetic anisotropy. In this regard, octacyanometalates [MIV/V(CN)8]4–/3– (M = Nb, Mo, W) are certainly promising, as their eight coordination sites and stereochemical flexibility enhance dynamic changes during sorption processes and facilitate the construction of various chiral motifs and topologies. Several two- and three-dimensional chiral and guest-responsive systems based on 3d metal ions and octacyanides have been investigated. We have focused on the unexplored area of one-dimensional (1D) systems combining chirality, slow magnetic relaxation, and microporosity. The general synthetic methodology is to employ anisotropic metal centers and appropriate organic ligands to ensure (a) the desired dimensionality; (b) good magnetic isolation of the chains, which is essential for slow magnetic relaxation; (c) chirality; and (d) microporous character. The last point is especially challenging, as 1D chains are typically arranged in parallel and solvent exchange causes their random reorientation. We overcame these difficulties by using the chiral rigid tridentate Pybox derivative 2,2′-(2,6-pyridinediyl)bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazoline) (iPr-Pybox) along with internally anisotropic CoII centers and paramagnetic [WV(CN)8]3– ions. We report the synthesis, crystal structures, and properties of 1D bimetallic {[CoII((S,S)-iPrPybox)(MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2·​5.5MeOH·​0.5H2O} n (1-SS) and {[CoII((R,R)-iPr-Pybox)(MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2·​5.5MeOH·​0.5H2O} n (1-RR) chains combining chirality with magnetic anisotropy, leading to single-chain-magnet behavior.
elements.clean_text: A considerable number of enantiopure chiral and microporous magnets have been characterized. Among them, extensive research has been devoted to cyano-bridged bimetallic assemblies, which exhibit a wide range of magnetic properties, including magnetic ordering, spin bistability, and magnetic anisotropy. In this regard, octacyanometalates [MIV/V(CN)8]4-/3- (M = Nb, Mo, W) are certainly promising, as their eight coordination sites and stereochemical flexibility enhance dynamic changes during sorption processes and facilitate the construction of various chiral motifs and topologies. Several two- and three-dimensional chiral and guest-responsive systems based on 3d metal ions and octacyanides have been investigated. We have focused on the unexplored area of one-dimensional (1D) systems combining chirality, slow magnetic relaxation, and microporosity. The general synthetic methodology is to employ anisotropic metal centers and appropriate organic ligands to ensure (a) the desired dimensionality; (b) good magnetic isolation of the chains, which is essential for slow magnetic relaxation; (c) chirality; and (d) microporous character. The last point is especially challenging, as 1D chains are typically arranged in parallel and solvent exchange causes their random reorientation. We overcame these difficulties by using the chiral rigid tridentate Pybox derivative 2,2'-(2,6-pyridinediyl)bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazoline) (iPr-Pybox) along with internally anisotropic CoII centers and paramagnetic [WV(CN)8]3- ions. We report the synthesis, crystal structures, and properties of 1D bimetallic {[CoII((S,S)-iPrPybox)(MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2⋅5.5MeOH⋅0.5H2O} n  (1-SS) and {[CoII((R,R)-iPr-Pybox)(MeOH)]3[WV(CN)8]2⋅5.5MeOH⋅0.5H2O} n  (1-RR) chains combining chirality with magnetic anisotropy, leading to single-chain-magnet behavior.

elements.content: 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) were obtained as orange rhombic plates from mixtures of Na3[WV(CN)8]·4H2O and CoIICl2·6H2O with (S,S)- and (R,R)-iPr-Pybox, respectively, in methanol upon the addition of diisopropyl ether. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that 1-(SS) is a 1D cyano-bridged molecular polymer with 3,2-topology that crystallizes in the chiral C2 space group (Figure ; also see Tables S1–S4 and Figures S1–S3 in the ). Each chain is built from {[cis-CoII(NC)2]2WV 2} squares connected via {trans-CoII(NC)2} moieties. The asymmetric unit contains three CoII and two [WV(CN)8]3– ions. Both [W1V(CN)8]3– and [W2V(CN)8]3– form three cyanide bridges each, and their geometries are between square-antiprismal (SAPR-8) and dodecahedral (DD-8) (). All of the CoII ions are six-coordinate and adopt a distorted octahedral geometry. Co1 is coordinated with two cyanide N atoms trans to each other, three meridionally arranged Pybox N atoms, and one methanol O atom. Co2 and Co3 have similar coordination spheres but with a cis configuration of the cyanide ligands. Molecular chains of 1-(SS) are arranged crosswise, as half of chains are situated in the [110] direction while the remaining ones lie along [1̅10]. This gives a chiral porous supramolecular network with vast channels along the c axis (Figure ). From the viewpoint of the W–Co skeleton, these channels have a decagonal shape limited by six CoII and four WV centers. Their dimensions are 15.3 Å × 15.1 Å × 14.9 Å, and the cross-sectional area is 178.1 Å2. They are filled by weakly bonded methanol (). The crystal structure of 1-(RR) is an almost ideal structural mirror image of 1-(SS) (Figure ). The coordination skeleton, geometries of the metal centers, and size of the channels in 1-(RR) are identical to those in 1-(SS) ().
elements.clean_text: 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) were obtained as orange rhombic plates from mixtures of Na3[WV(CN)8]⋅4H2O and CoIICl2⋅6H2O with (S,S)- and (R,R)-iPr-Pybox, respectively, in methanol upon the addition of diisopropyl ether. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that 1-(SS) is a 1D cyano-bridged molecular polymer with 3,2-topology that crystallizes in the chiral C2 space group (Figure ; also see Tables S1-S4 and Figures S1-S3 in the ). Each chain is built from {[cis-CoII(NC)2]2WV 2} squares connected via {trans-CoII(NC)2} moieties. The asymmetric unit contains three CoII and two [WV(CN)8]3- ions. Both [W1V(CN)8]3- and [W2V(CN)8]3- form three cyanide bridges each, and their geometries are between square-antiprismal (SAPR-8) and dodecahedral (DD-8) (). All of the CoII ions are six-coordinate and adopt a distorted octahedral geometry. Co1 is coordinated with two cyanide N atoms trans to each other, three meridionally arranged Pybox N atoms, and one methanol O atom. Co2 and Co3 have similar coordination spheres but with a cis configuration of the cyanide ligands. Molecular chains of 1-(SS) are arranged crosswise, as half of chains are situated in the [110] direction while the remaining ones lie along [1̅10]. This gives a chiral porous supramolecular network with vast channels along the c axis (Figure ). From the viewpoint of the W-Co skeleton, these channels have a decagonal shape limited by six CoII and four WV centers. Their dimensions are 15.3 Å × 15.1 Å × 14.9 Å, and the cross-sectional area is 178.1 Å2. They are filled by weakly bonded methanol (). The crystal structure of 1-(RR) is an almost ideal structural mirror image of 1-(SS) (Figure ). The coordination skeleton, geometries of the metal centers, and size of the channels in 1-(RR) are identical to those in 1-(SS) ().

elements.content: Crystal structures of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR): (top) 1D coordination polymers; (bottom) crossed arrangement of chains giving microporous networks.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR): (top) 1D coordination polymers; (bottom) crossed arrangement of chains giving microporous networks.

elements.content: To examine the optical properties, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra together with natural circular dichroism (NCD) spectra were acquired (Figure ). Besides the UV absorption, 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) exhibit a broad band between 400 and 700 nm with a maximum at 490 nm. Deconvolution of the spectrum gave four main components with maxima at 335 (peak 1), 465 (peak 2), 530 (peak 3), and 590 nm (peak 4). They can be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer from CN– to WV [E″(2B1) → E′(2A2) and E″(2B1) → E′(2E); peak 1], metal-to-metal charge transfer (CoII HS → WV; peak 2), and d–d transitions in high-spin (HS) CoII centers [4T1g(4F) → 4T1g(4P) for peak 3; 4T1g → 4A2g for peak 4]. In NCD spectra, 1-(SS) exclusively shows a positive signal while 1-(RR) exhibits only a negative Cotton effect (Figure ). The shape of the NCD spectrum of 1-(SS) is close to that observed in the absorption mode, and the spectrum of 1-(RR) is its mirror image in relation to the baseline. These results clearly prove the enantiopure character of both compounds and show that chirality related to the ligand induces chirality in the whole structure.
elements.clean_text: To examine the optical properties, UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra together with natural circular dichroism (NCD) spectra were acquired (Figure ). Besides the UV absorption, 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) exhibit a broad band between 400 and 700 nm with a maximum at 490 nm. Deconvolution of the spectrum gave four main components with maxima at 335 (peak 1), 465 (peak 2), 530 (peak 3), and 590 nm (peak 4). They can be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer from CN- to WV [E"(2B1) → E'(2A2) and E"(2B1) → E'(2E); peak 1], metal-to-metal charge transfer (CoII HS → WV; peak 2), and d-d transitions in high-spin (HS) CoII centers [4T1g(4F) → 4T1g(4P) for peak 3; 4T1g → 4A2g for peak 4]. In NCD spectra, 1-(SS) exclusively shows a positive signal while 1-(RR) exhibits only a negative Cotton effect (Figure ). The shape of the NCD spectrum of 1-(SS) is close to that observed in the absorption mode, and the spectrum of 1-(RR) is its mirror image in relation to the baseline. These results clearly prove the enantiopure character of both compounds and show that chirality related to the ligand induces chirality in the whole structure.

elements.content: (top) UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra and (bottom) NCD spectra of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR).
elements.clean_text: 2  (top) UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra and (bottom) NCD spectra of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR).

elements.content: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) are presented in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility–temperature product (χM T) at room temperature is 9.6 K cm3 mol–1 (SS and RR), corresponding to uncoupled CoII 3WV 2 units (S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0, S CoHS = 3/2, g Co = 2.5). Upon cooling, χM T slowly decreases, reaching a shallow minimum at ∼47 K; sharply increases to a maximum of 25.6 (SS) or 27.1 K cm3 mol–1 (RR) at 3.2 K as a result of CoII–WV magnetic coupling; and finally decreases because of single-ion effects of CoII. The value of the magnetization (M) at 2 K under a magnetic field of 7 T is 7.2 Nβ (SS and RR) which is situated between the expected values of 8.6 Nβ for ferromagnetic and 4.6 Nβ for antiferromagnetic CoII 3WV 2 units (assuming S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0, S Co,eff = 1/2, g Co,average = 13/3). This indicates that CoII–WV magnetic coupling leads to a specific spin arrangement with half of the WV centers coupled ferromagnetically with CoII neighbors and the other half coupled antiferromagnetically (Figure bottom).
elements.clean_text: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) are presented in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility-temperature product (χM T) at room temperature is 9.6 K cm3 mol-1 (SS and RR), corresponding to uncoupled CoII 3WV 2 units (S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0, S CoHS  = 3/2, g Co = 2.5). Upon cooling, χM T slowly decreases, reaching a shallow minimum at ~47 K; sharply increases to a maximum of 25.6 (SS) or 27.1 K cm3 mol-1 (RR) at 3.2 K as a result of CoII-WV magnetic coupling; and finally decreases because of single-ion effects of CoII. The value of the magnetization (M) at 2 K under a magnetic field of 7 T is 7.2 Nβ (SS and RR) which is situated between the expected values of 8.6 Nβ for ferromagnetic and 4.6 Nβ for antiferromagnetic CoII 3WV 2 units (assuming S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0, S Co,eff = 1/2, g Co,average = 13/3). This indicates that CoII-WV magnetic coupling leads to a specific spin arrangement with half of the WV centers coupled ferromagnetically with CoII neighbors and the other half coupled antiferromagnetically (Figure  bottom).

elements.content: (top) Temperature dependence of χM T (H = 2 kOe). (middle) Field dependence of the magnetization (T = 2 K). (bottom) One of the two possible spin arrangements (the other possibility is shown in Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: 3  (top) Temperature dependence of χM T (H = 2 kOe). (middle) Field dependence of the magnetization (T = 2 K). (bottom) One of the two possible spin arrangements (the other possibility is shown in Figure S5).

elements.content: Figure shows plots of χM T versus T and M versus magnetic field (H) for single-crystalline 1-(SS) and, for comparison, powder forms of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR). Over the whole temperature range, the χM T values for the b axis are greater than those for the powder sample, whereas for the a and c directions, the signals are lower. On cooling, χM T decreases slightly for all axes, with c having the most significant minimum and b a merely vestigial one. For the b axis, the magnetization reached 8.5 Nβ, corresponding to g Co,b = 5.6 (assuming S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0, S Co,eff = 1/2). For the a and c axes, the estimated g factors are 4.3 and 4.6, respectively. Figure a shows the rotation dependence of M measured in the ac, ab, and bc planes. The easy axis of magnetization was found to lie in the ac plane 70° from a going toward c within the obtuse angle, which corresponds to the shorter diagonal of the unit-cell wall (the [101] direction). Moreover, the hard axis was also observed to lie in the ac plane and cover the second diagonal (the [101̅] direction) (Figure c). The magnetization along the easy axis saturated at 8.7 Nβ, giving a high g Co value of 5.8, while for the hard axis, M reached only 3.5 Nβ without saturation.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows plots of χM T versus T and M versus magnetic field (H) for single-crystalline 1-(SS) and, for comparison, powder forms of 1-(SS) and 1-(RR). Over the whole temperature range, the χM T values for the b axis are greater than those for the powder sample, whereas for the a and c directions, the signals are lower. On cooling, χM T decreases slightly for all axes, with c having the most significant minimum and b a merely vestigial one. For the b axis, the magnetization reached 8.5 Nβ, corresponding to g Co,b  = 5.6 (assuming S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0, S Co,eff = 1/2). For the a and c axes, the estimated g factors are 4.3 and 4.6, respectively. Figure a shows the rotation dependence of M measured in the ac, ab, and bc planes. The easy axis of magnetization was found to lie in the ac plane 70° from a going toward c within the obtuse angle, which corresponds to the shorter diagonal of the unit-cell wall (the [101] direction). Moreover, the hard axis was also observed to lie in the ac plane and cover the second diagonal (the [101̅] direction) (Figure c). The magnetization along the easy axis saturated at 8.7 Nβ, giving a high g Co value of 5.8, while for the hard axis, M reached only 3.5 Nβ without saturation.

elements.content: Magnetic properties of 1-(SS): (a) rotation dependence of M measured in various planes (T = 2 K, H = 2000 Oe); (b) M vs H curves for the easy and hard axes; (c) arrangement of the hard and easy axes in relation to the structure; (d) geometries of the CoII ions.
elements.clean_text: 4  Magnetic properties of 1-(SS): (a) rotation dependence of M measured in various planes (T = 2 K, H = 2000 Oe); (b) M vs H curves for the easy and hard axes; (c) arrangement of the hard and easy axes in relation to the structure; (d) geometries of the CoII ions.

elements.content: Neither the easy axis nor the hard axis is parallel or perpendicular to the chains; both axes are instead related to the arrangement of the CoII moieties. On the basis of the geometrical parameters (Co–N and Co–O bond lengths and N–Co–N and N–Co–O angles; ), the CoII ions in 1-(SS) are tetragonally deformed octahedra with the elongation along two of the Co–Noxazoline bonds. The angular distortion toward the pyridine rings plays a minor role (Figure d). The easy axis of magnetization is consistent with elongation of the axes of the Co2 and Co3 centers, while the hard axis is almost perpendicular to them (Figure c). Co1 is not important here, as its elongation axis is perpendicular to the ac plane. The rotation dependences for other planes can be similarly explained (). Thus, the magnetic anisotropy of 1-(SS) is controlled by the single-ion anisotropy of the CoII ions, with the easy axis approximated by the elongation direction along the Co–Noxazoline bonds. Such behavior has been observed in other reported magnetic systems based on elongated octahedral CoII ions.
elements.clean_text: Neither the easy axis nor the hard axis is parallel or perpendicular to the chains; both axes are instead related to the arrangement of the CoII moieties. On the basis of the geometrical parameters (Co-N and Co-O bond lengths and N-Co-N and N-Co-O angles; ), the CoII ions in 1-(SS) are tetragonally deformed octahedra with the elongation along two of the Co-Noxazoline bonds. The angular distortion toward the pyridine rings plays a minor role (Figure d). The easy axis of magnetization is consistent with elongation of the axes of the Co2 and Co3 centers, while the hard axis is almost perpendicular to them (Figure c). Co1 is not important here, as its elongation axis is perpendicular to the ac plane. The rotation dependences for other planes can be similarly explained (). Thus, the magnetic anisotropy of 1-(SS) is controlled by the single-ion anisotropy of the CoII ions, with the easy axis approximated by the elongation direction along the Co-Noxazoline bonds. Such behavior has been observed in other reported magnetic systems based on elongated octahedral CoII ions.

elements.content: The field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) M versus T curves for 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) do not diverge (), indicating the absence of long-range magnetic ordering and good isolation of the molecular chains. Together with the significant anisotropy, this leads to a frequency dependence of the out-of-plane alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility (χM ″) in the lowest temperature regime, suggesting the onset of slow magnetic relaxation (Figure ). Despite the fact maxima of χM ″ were not observed even with an applied dc magnetic field (H dc), we estimated the values for the relaxation time (τ0) and the activation energy (E a) using plots of ln(χM ″/χM ′) versus T –1 (where χM ′ is the in-plane ac magnetic susceptibility), as described by Pardo and co-workers (Figure ). Obtained values (τ0 = 5 × 10–7 s, E a = 6 K) suggested a single-chain magnet behavior.
elements.clean_text: The field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) M versus T curves for 1-(SS) and 1-(RR) do not diverge (), indicating the absence of long-range magnetic ordering and good isolation of the molecular chains. Together with the significant anisotropy, this leads to a frequency dependence of the out-of-plane alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility (χM ") in the lowest temperature regime, suggesting the onset of slow magnetic relaxation (Figure ). Despite the fact maxima of χM " were not observed even with an applied dc magnetic field (H dc), we estimated the values for the relaxation time (τ0) and the activation energy (E a) using plots of ln(χM "/χM ') versus T -1 (where χM ' is the in-plane ac magnetic susceptibility), as described by Pardo and co-workers (Figure ). Obtained values (τ0 = 5 × 10-7 s, E  a  = 6 K) suggested a single-chain magnet behavior.

elements.content: χM ″ vs T plots at H dc = 0 and (inset) ln(χM ″/χM ′) vs T –1 plots for 1-(SS) at various ac frequencies.
elements.clean_text: 5  χM " vs T plots at H dc = 0 and (inset) ln(χM "/χM ') vs T -1 plots for 1-(SS) at various ac frequencies.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared two 1D cyano-bridged CoII–WV chains combining chirality and magnetic anisotropy, leading to slow magnetic relaxation. This multifunctionality is directed by an organic Pybox ligand that (1) generates the 1D topology; (2) introduces optical chirality; (3) controls the magnetic anisotropy, as the decisive elongation of the octahedral CoII moieties is connected with the alignment of the Pybox rings; and (4) contributes to the slow magnetic relaxation, ensuring good magnetic isolation. The applied ligand is also responsible for the crossed arrangement of chains, giving the supramolecular network with vast channels. This last feature opens a great perspective in exploring the dynamic character of our materials, as methanol occupying the micropores can be replaced by water without loss of crystallinity (). Research along this line is now in progress.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared two 1D cyano-bridged CoII-WV chains combining chirality and magnetic anisotropy, leading to slow magnetic relaxation. This multifunctionality is directed by an organic Pybox ligand that (1) generates the 1D topology; (2) introduces optical chirality; (3) controls the magnetic anisotropy, as the decisive elongation of the octahedral CoII moieties is connected with the alignment of the Pybox rings; and (4) contributes to the slow magnetic relaxation, ensuring good magnetic isolation. The applied ligand is also responsible for the crossed arrangement of chains, giving the supramolecular network with vast channels. This last feature opens a great perspective in exploring the dynamic character of our materials, as methanol occupying the micropores can be replaced by water without loss of crystallinity (). Research along this line is now in progress.

elements.content: Crystallographic data (CIF), details of design and synthesis, crystal data and structure refinement, structural views, results of continuous shape measure analysis and the dihedral angles method, ZFC and FC magnetization curves, detailed analysis of single-crystal magnetic data, and powder diffractograms of hydrated forms. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data (CIF), details of design and synthesis, crystal data and structure refinement, structural views, results of continuous shape measure analysis and the dihedral angles method, ZFC and FC magnetization curves, detailed analysis of single-crystal magnetic data, and powder diffractograms of hydrated forms. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Conjunction of Chirality
and Slow Magnetic Relaxation
in the Supramolecular Network Constructed of Crossed Cyano-Bridged
CoII–WV Molecular Chains
